Lighting Control Rack Overhaul https://jeff.glass/oneoff/lightingcloset/ Wed, 24 Nov 2021 10:16:14 -0600 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/lightingcloset/

I tasked myself with overhauling one of the lighting control closets at work. This used to house a 1995 Unison Heritage lighting controller for archetectural control, as well as an MA2 remote playback unit to control some LED fixtures and moving lights. It was all housed in an abysmal rolling rack with no connectors on it; why the rack needed to roll is beyond me. I packaged it up into a freestanding rack and replaced the Unison Heritage processor with an ETC Nomad controller for proper entertainment lighting control; installed a new network switch; and fully documented the rack’s purpose, wiring, and configuration.

KVM Stand https://jeff.glass/oneoff/kvm-stand/ Tue, 09 Nov 2021 10:16:14 -0600 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/kvm-stand/

My work often involves switching between several computers - a laptop, a beefier desktop, an ‘IT Sanctioned’ clean machine with access to the work network, and a temporary line to whatever computer’s on the workbench. To improve the ergonomics of using the KVM switch, I designed and 3D-printed a small stand to hold the switch controls, then labelled it using an old embossing Dymo label maker.

Airflow Passthrough https://jeff.glass/oneoff/airpassthrough/ Thu, 04 Nov 2021 13:17:14 -0500 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/airpassthrough/

The airflow situation is often very stuffy, especially in the summer months. The adjacent workroom has abundant AC, enough to keep a full room full of incandescent fixtures at bay. I punched through the wall (with permission) and mounted the fan from an old server rack over the top. I added grills to both sides to prevent knicked fingers. I designed and 3d-printed a cover with locking knurled handles to cover the hole when I’m not present or the temperature is fine.

Ahab's Harpoon https://jeff.glass/oneoff/am-hpf/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/am-hpf/

For a production of Moby Dick, the director wanted Ahab’s harpoon to glow with a heated, unearthly light just before the second intermission. I glued some warm-white LED tape just below the plexiglass tines of the harpoon, and dimmed them with an RC4 Wireless Dimmer. The power came from three 18650 lithium ion batteries.

AM Highpass Filter https://jeff.glass/oneoff/harpoon/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/harpoon/

As I was getting started building amateur radios, I ran into an issue whenever I would go to operate by the lakefront in Chicago. The direct line-of-site to downtown meant my frontend was getting absolutely blasted through by the large AM transmitter sites downtown. I built a small (admittedly unshielded) high pass filter to cut off everything below about 3 MHz, and this helped some.

G3UUR Crystal Tester https://jeff.glass/oneoff/g3uur/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/g3uur/

When one is building a crystal filter for SSB reception in amateur radio, it’s critical to know some of the properties of the crystals one is using. Especially its exact resonant frequency, motional inductance and capacitance. THe G3UUR Crystal Checker setup makes these relatively easy to determine, by switching an additional series capacitance in and out.

Home Radio Station https://jeff.glass/oneoff/radio-shack/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/radio-shack/

As part of my pursuits as a ham radio operator, I set about to install a humble ham radio station in preparation for the Winter of 2021-22. Prior to this, I had been limited to operating entirely portably, outdoors and away from the noise of the city. As the days grew colder, I added a couple of ELFA shelves underneath my 3D printer, to place my FT-891, antenna tuner, and a few other accessories. It works alright - there is indeed a lot of RF noise in the city. But it means I don’t have to wander out in to the cold just to play a little radio.

Homemade Bacon https://jeff.glass/oneoff/bacon/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/bacon/

During a summer sabatical, I experimented with making my own bacon. I obtained roughly 4 lbs of pork belly from a local butcher, wet-brined it for about a week in the fridge, then smoked half and oven-roasted the other half. The slow smoked was miles better, but I had more issues with heat-control, so some of the additional flavor was simply from caramalization on the outside.

Lighting XKeys https://jeff.glass/oneoff/ion-xkeys/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/ion-xkeys/

A very popular lighting controller in the theatrical nonprofit world is the ETC Ion, which was my primary controller two lighting jobs ago now. I found that a 16-key set of Programming XKeys fits just right alongside the control console. The keys act like a USB keyboard to run pre-programmed macros on the console to replicate common or longwinded sequences of keystrokes.

Yorkshire Pudding https://jeff.glass/oneoff/yorkshire/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000 https://jeff.glass/oneoff/yorkshire/

A traditional holiday dessert at my inlaws' is Yorkshire Pudding. A simple egg and flour batter is poured into piping-hot muffin tins filled with melted butted and drippings from the holiday roast, which then rise and pop up into fluffy, delicious, buttery muffin things. Very tasty, would recommend.
